title: RBS Pledges End to Coal Funding, Stricter Oil Rules
summary: Bank's announcement is the latest environmental pledge from a multinational company. Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC said it would end financing for coal by 2030 and place stricter rules on oil-and-gas majors it works with, joining other companies that have made similar sustainability moves as investors and the public demand action on climate change.

title: States Spurn Drug Industry's Opioid-Settlement Offer
summary: Dissenting states want the wholesalers to contribute between $22 billion and $32 billion. An $18 billion offer from three major drug wholesalers aimed at settling litigation over their alleged role in the opioid crisis fell through, after more than 20 state attorneys general rejected it in a letter to the companies' law firms this week.

title: Avenatti Found Guilty in Extortion Case
summary: Lawyer for Stormy Daniels convicted on charges linked to effort to extort millions from Nike. Michael Avenatti, who rose to national fame as the brash, camera-ready lawyer for adult-film actress Stormy Daniels, was found guilty Friday on charges that he tried to extort more than $20 million from Nike Inc. by threatening to expose damaging information about the company.

title: Truth in Constitutional Amending
summary: Justice Ginsburg says the push for the Equal Rights Amendment should start over.. Everything old is new again in politics, including socialism. So why not the long lost Equal Rights Amendment that failed in the 1980s? The answer came Monday from no less than Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, who said at Georgetown University's law school that ERA supporters are obliged to "start over."

title: Donald Trump, Mastermind
summary: Liberals detect a devious cover-up plot with Bill Barr.. A hilarious Saturday Night Live skit from the 1980s had the late Phil Hartman playing Ronald Reagan as an amiable dunce in public but a devious mastermind behind closed doors. That routine came to mind Friday as we read the conspiracy theories on the left about Attorney General William Barr's public criticism of President Trump's tweets on criminal cases.

title: Mercurial and Moody in Manila
summary: Duterte ends a pact with the U.S. as China expands its influence.. Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte this week announced the termination of a security pact that underpins the U.S.-Philippines alliance, and President Trump responded by celebrating potential savings for the American fisc. The good news is that this isn't a popular decision in Manila or Washington, and there's time to save the agreement.

title: New Developments Feed Debate on Justice Department Independence
summary: Prosecutors decline to charge McCabe; outside prosecutor appointed to examine investigation into Flynn. A day after Attorney General William Barr took to television in an effort to quiet worries over the political independence of the Justice Department, new developments fanned both sides of the argument.

title: U.S. Pension Insurer Scrutinizing Deals Between McClatchy, Hedge Fund
summary: The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp. is examining debt transactions between McClatchy and Chatham Asset Management that has positioned the hedge fund to own the publisher out of bankruptcy. The U.S. government's pension insurer is demanding more information about financial transactions between McClatchy Co. and the New Jersey-based hedge fund angling to become the majority shareholder of the nation's second-largest newspaper publisher when it exits bankruptcy.

title: Carnival, T-Mobile, Barclays: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Here are seven major companies whose stocks moved on the week's news. Carnival Corp.

title: How Iowa and New Hampshire Have Reshaped Democratic Race
summary: Once atop the national polls, Joe Biden slips to fifth in vote share and delegates. Despite a still unsettled outcome in Iowa and a tight finish in New Hampshire, the first two nominating contests have dramatically altered the contours of the Democratic presidential race.

title: Airline Group's Offices Raided by Colombian Prosecutors
summary: Avianca Holdings is facing corruption investigations by authorities in Colombia and the U.S.. Colombian authorities raided the offices of Avianca Holdings SA as part of what the country's prosecutors described as a transnational bribery investigation.

title: Trump Administration to Deploy Enforcement Personnel to Sanctuary Cities
summary: U.S. Customs and Border Protection sending 100 officers and agents to supplement operations targeting illegal immigrants. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration is deploying 100 officers and agents from the southern border to sanctuary cities in the U.S. to assist in arrest operations targeting immigrants who are in the U.S. illegally, according to two people familiar with the plan.

title: Canada Seeks Talks to End Rail Blockades
summary: A blockade in northern British Columbia ends, but protests in Ontario and Quebec continue. OTTAWA-The Canadian government said Friday it would pursue negotiations to end the blockades that have thwarted rail traffic across the country for more than a week, even as the country's biggest railroad petitioned for protesters to be forcibly removed.

title: 'Citizen Reporters' Review: The Cyclone and the Trust Buster
summary: Samuel Sidney McClure once said to his wife, 'I would rather edit a magazine than be president of the United States.'. Samuel Sidney McClure once said to his wife: "I would rather edit a magazine than be president of the United States."

title: Vindman, Who Drew Trump's Ire, Won't Face Disciplinary Action
summary: Former White House aide had testified about Trump's call with Ukraine's president. WASHINGTON-The U.S. Army said it has no plans to investigate Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman, after President Trump earlier this week suggested the former White House aide who voiced concerns about his actions toward Ukraine should face disciplinary action.

title: Kraft Bonds Tumble After Downgrades to Junk Rating
summary: Company could account for 2% of high-yield market.

title: States Look to Fill Funding Gaps for Clinics Providing Abortions
summary: Many clinics are trying to make up budget shortfalls caused by Trump administration's changes to Title X policy. Maine lawmakers are weighing legislation that would restore funding to the state's family-planning network after abortion providers exited a federal funding program last year over policy changes.

title: Lender Grabs Ownership of Beverly Hills Spec Home Once Listed for $100 Million
summary: Developer Nile Niami marketed the mansion known as Opus for three years and made several price cuts. Once listed for $100 million, an elaborate Beverly Hills spec house with a champagne vault and a "car museum" has been on the market for about three years, undergoing several major price cuts. Now, the developer, prolific spec home builder Nile Niami, says he's sold the property, known as "Opus," for roughly $40 million. But the reality is a little more complicated.

title: We're From the Government and We're Here to Build a Bike Path
summary: Municipal officials are using eminent domain to take private property for recreational uses.. A handful of farmers in Ohio's Mahoning County are getting an unpleasant lesson in government power at the hands of a local park district. Mill Creek MetroParks, a public agency governed by five unelected commissioners, wants to take over an abandoned railroad line running through about a dozen local farms for a recreational bike path. Last year, when landowners balked at the idea of strangers wandering across their properties, the park district decided to invoke eminent domain and gain right of way.

title: George Washington's Birthday and the Battle for History
summary: Rangers giving tours go off script about the American Revolution. Time to rein in the Park Service.. George Washington's birthday is celebrated on Monday, so consider this thought experiment: It is 2026 and Washington and close military advisers like Alexander Hamilton return for a 250th-anniversary ride on the eight decisive battlefields where American independence was won.

title: South Bend's 'Beta' Test for Mayor Pete
summary: Buttigieg rode the national recovery to some modest economic gains but ran into trouble on the hard urban problems of crime and racial politics.. Pete Buttigieg seeks to become the first Democrat since 1924 to win the presidential nomination without serving as governor or U.S. senator. He's pitching his experience as a small-city mayor as just what the country needs: "We have to start getting Washington to look like our best-run cities and towns, instead of the other way around," he said last weekend in New Hampshire. The argument was enough to carry Mr. Buttigieg, 38, to a close second-place finish in Tuesday's primary.

title: A Red Preoccupation With Blue Pictures
summary: My East German handler railed against pornography until he asked me to bring some from West Berlin.. I lived in West Berlin in 1961-62, studying East German law on a Fulbright scholarship, for which I frequently crossed the Wall into East Berlin to visit their courts. I always had to be accompanied by a minder-Herr Sprissny, the East Berlin liaison between the press and the courts.

title: Payments Tech Provider Toast Raises $400 Million at $4.9 Billion Valuation
summary: The Boston startup plans to expand its offerings to include financial products to fund restaurant business growth. Toast Inc., a startup that provides payment processing hardware and cloud-based software for restaurants, raised $400 million in Series F funding, as the company expands its product lineup.

title: 'Congress at War' and 'When It Was Grand' Review: The Great Emancipators
summary: Abraham Lincoln did not act alone, and very often did not act as boldly as his strongest supporters would have liked.. In the beginning, Republicans stood far to the left of Democrats on most issues. Founded in 1854 as an antislavery political organization, the Republican Party made a strong bid for the presidency just two years later, when John C. Frémont ran against proslavery Democrat James Buchanan and Millard Fillmore of the soon-to-expire Whig party. In 1860 the Republicans gained victory with the election of Abraham Lincoln, which prompted the secession of 11 Democratic-controlled slave states. Lincoln's election was accompanied by a Republican sweep of both houses of Congress, thanks in part to Southern Democrats defecting to the Confederacy.

title: 'Counterpoint' Review: Variations on a Theme
summary: Revisiting the past through an attempt to master one of Bach's keyboard masterpieces.. When a musician sits down and tries to play something for the first time, an extraordinary thing can happen, writes the critic Philip Kennicott. If he or she has heard the music before but never attempted it, a feeling not unlike the flush of romantic love can occur. For a few carefree minutes, there is no worrying over mistakes or fear of the hard work ahead: There is only novel recognition. "The conjuring of these voices with your own hands gives them a surfeit of charm, rather like meeting someone in the flesh after having seen only a photograph."

title: Bloomberg Buys the Democratic Elite
summary: Putting dollar signs in the eyes of activists is not the same as catching fire with the voting public.. If one news outlet had the manpower and mind-set to dig cynically into the many ways Mike Bloomberg is spending his money to become president, it would be Bloomberg News-if it weren't owned by Mike Bloomberg.

title: In Wuhan, China's Virus Outbreak Overwhelms Residential Committees
summary: Most Popular News. WUHAN, China-Local Communist Party representative Xiao Lifang has been working nearly nonstop since the outbreak of a deadly virus here, helping to figure out who needs to be quarantined or hospitalized, checking temperatures, and delivering food and medicine to the thousands of residents she oversees.

title: U.S. Stocks Post Weekly Gains
summary: The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite swung between small gains and losses Friday and ended the session higher. U.S. stocks were little changed Friday but ended the week with gains as investors' concerns about a sharp rise in coronavirus cases faded.

summary: Council's committee on standards and ethics said it opened a new investigation of Andy King following new allegations of misconduct.

summary: Case against movie mogul of rape and other sex crimes goes to the jury next week. Manhattan prosecutors implored a jury to find Harvey Weinstein guilty of sex crimes in a searing closing argument Friday, calling him a narcissistic "predator" who sexually assaulted women angling for entertainment jobs, then isolated and humiliated them into keeping quiet.

title: History Through a Poet's Eyes
summary: Carl Sandburg's books on Abraham Lincoln, far from traditional biography, remain unmatched for their vivid combination of mood, incident and epochal sweep..

summary: Money managers say they have faith that epidemic will be contained. The coronavirus outbreak has closed factories, curbed spending and disrupted supply chains in the world's second-largest economy. But U.S. stocks have held close to records.

title: Sprint Sizzles, Airbnb Disappoints and Earnings Season Drags On
summary: We analyze the week's big news with major indexes on track for a second consecutive week of gains. Major U.S. stock indexes set fresh highs this week, but the coronavirus still dominated the news with more questions than answers.

title: Stanley Cohen, Nobel Winner, Identified Agents Spurring Growth of Cells
summary: Biochemist's experiments in 1950s deepened understanding of cancer and led to new treatments. In the early 1950s, Stanley Cohen met Rita Levi-Montalcini at Washington University in St. Louis. The son of Jewish immigrants from Russia, he was a young researcher in biochemistry. Thirteen years older, she was a Jewish neurologist who emigrated to the U.S. from Italy after World War II.

title: Carmelo Anthony Looks to Score $12.85 Million for New York Condo
summary: The basketball star and former Knicks forward is selling his Chelsea home with three living rooms. Basketball star Carmelo Anthony is asking $12.85 million for his New York City condo, a five-bedroom spread overlooking Manhattan's High Line park.

title: Mississippi Capital Prepares for Flooding
summary: Nearly 2,500 structures are under threat as river continues to rise and more rain is forecasted. The Pearl River is expected to crest nearly 10 feet above its flood stage in Jackson, Miss., on Saturday, prompting evacuation orders and a state of emergency declaration by the city's mayor.

title: The All-Star NBA Agent Who Is Almost as Young as His Clients
summary: Jason Glushon, at 34, has negotiated four professional basketball contracts worth $100 million. 'If all my clients are happy, then I get to be happy.'. Jason Glushon learned about the existence of sports agents the way that most people did: He saw the 1996 movie "Jerry Maguire." It would be a long time before he would become a sports agent himself. He was still in elementary school.

title: In Brazil, President Fills Inner Circle With Fellow Military Men
summary: Walter Braga Netto is set to take over as chief of staff, becoming the ninth member in Bolsonaro's cabinet to come from the armed forces. SÃO PAULO-A Brazilian army general is set to take over as chief of staff Tuesday as President Jair Bolsonaro fills his inner circle with fellow military men, distancing himself from a political establishment tarnished by corruption.

title: Google in Talks to Pay Publishers for News
summary: The search giant is in talks with some publishers about paying a fee for content that would be part of a news product. Alphabet Inc.'s Google is in talks with publishers about paying a licensing fee for content in a news product, according to people familiar with the matter, a move that would mark a shift in the search giant's relationship with news organizations.

title: WHO Says It Hasn't Advised About Altering Olympics Due to Virus
summary: IOC had suggested no need to make contingency plans on Tokyo Games. TOKYO-The World Health Organization said Friday that it hasn't advised the International Olympic Committee about whether it should change plans for the Games in Tokyo this summer because of the epidemic caused by a new coronavirus.

title: Crude Prices Shrug Off Coronavirus Worries
summary: For the week, U.S. crude futures rose 3.4% to $52.05 a barrel, while Brent rose 5.2%. Oil prices rose this week, snapping a five-week losing streak and shrugging off a downbeat U.S. inventory report, revisions lower in crude-demand growth forecasts and fresh worries about the scope of the coronavirus outbreak in China.

title: White House Cites 2002 Iraq War Measure to Justify Killing Soleimani
summary: Authorization and Constitution gave Trump a right to strike Iranian general, administration says; 'Absurd,' a top Democratic lawmaker responds. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration justified the Jan. 3 strike that killed Iranian Gen. Qassem Soleimani in part by citing an 18-year-old congressional authorization that paved the way for the 2003 invasion of Iraq and overthrow of leader Saddam Hussein, according to a White House notice made public on Friday.

title: U.S.-Europe Divide Gets Spotlight at Security Conference
summary: Representatives of the U.S. and its European allies emphasize different parts of the world. MUNICH-Top diplomats and security officials from the U.S. and Europe sought to bridge some of the biggest security divides straining the trans-Atlantic alliance, amid disputes over topics ranging from Iran to military spending.

title: Battle for House Intensifies After Impeachment
summary: Democrats in districts won by Trump hope to emphasize legislation, while GOP ties them to impeachment votes. WASHINGTON-House lawmakers are readying to campaign in the post-impeachment landscape, with Democrats eager to focus on policy issues and Republicans planning to attack swing-district Democrats for voting to remove a president whom many of their constituents support.

title: Coronavirus Creates Domino Effect in Automotive Supply Chain
summary: Fiat Chrysler plant to shut down in Europe while GM production outages threatened in U.S.. Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV said it is temporarily halting production at a car factory in Serbia because it can't get parts from China, a sign of how the coronavirus outbreak is creating a domino effect in a straining global supply chain.

title: Building a Good Federal Architecture Policy
summary: Those politicians who espouse the primacy of the individual over the centralized state cannot also argue in favor of limiting design choice in the name of order, control, republican virtue or whatever classical tradition is taken to represent today.. Regarding Myron Magnet's "Drain the Swamp of Ugly Architecture" (op-ed, Feb. 7): Those politicians who espouse the primacy of the individual over the centralized state cannot also argue in favor of limiting design choice in the name of order, control, republican virtue or whatever classical tradition is taken to represent today.

title: GI Bill Design Is Better Than Student Loans
summary: The GI Bill was a cost-of-living stipend, plus free tuition. This forced everyone-colleges, students, book publishers and landlords-to keep their prices in line.. Michael Bennett's Feb. 11 letter ("Medici Would Be Skeptical on Student Loans") refers to the return on investment on the GI Bill versus the student-loan program. The GI Bill was a cost-of-living stipend, plus free tuition. This, I submit, forced everyone-colleges, students, book publishers and landlords-to keep their prices in line because they knew to a penny how much (or how little) their buyers could afford.

title: The Carter Campaign and the 1976 Iowa Caucuses
summary: Gov. Jimmy Carter had superb campaign organizations in New Hampshire, Florida and Wisconsin, and he won those states. Second, third, or fourth in Iowa? It wouldn't have mattered.. It is with some amazement and amusement that I read Sam Walker's paean to Tom Whitney ("The Captain Class: The Snap Decision That Made the Iowa Caucuses," Exchange, Feb. 8).

title: Huawei's Strategy Lures 'Em In and Binds Increases
summary: I support Thomas J. Duesterberg's pro-active views, as I have often despaired at today's lack of a national telecoms vendor to compete in the 5G space.. I am an international telecoms and media executive and I support Thomas J. Duesterberg's pro-active views, as I have often despaired at today's lack of a national telecoms vendor to compete in the 5G space ("There Is a Better Alternative to Huawei," op-ed, Feb. 6). Why not focus on changing the equation with software and network virtualization rather than hardware?

title: Manchester City Is Hit With Two-Year Ban From Champions League
summary: The penalty issued by soccer's European governing body comes after the club was found in breach of rules on spending. Manchester City will be banned from the Champions League, club soccer's most prestigious tournament, for the next two seasons after being found in breach of rules on excessive spending, the sport's European governing body announced in an unprecedented judgment on Friday.

title: U.S. Consumer Spending Picks Up, While Manufacturing Declines
summary: Warm January boosts auto sales, building supplies but hurts clothing sales, industrial production. WASHINGTON-Consumer spending in the U.S. picked up slightly in January after a weak holiday season, while manufacturing started the year on a decline, suggesting forces that slowed 2019 growth continued at the start of this year.

title: Macron's Candidate for Paris Mayor Drops Out

President Emmanuel Macron's candidate for mayor of Paris quit the race Friday following allegations he sent a woman sexually explicit text messages, a major setback to the president's hopes of cementing his party's place in French politics.

title: Counting Rent Would Improve Credit Scores of Public-Housing Residents, HUD Finds
summary: Some housing advocates remain concerned full rent-payment histories would hurt tenants struggling the most to get by. title: Univision Nears Sale to Group Including Former Viacom Executive
summary: Spanish-language broadcaster has been running an auction process for months. title: Court Rejects White House Approval of Medicaid Work Requirements

title: China's Crisis Exposes a Badly Flawed Model
summary: Central control and fear of reprisal have made it much more difficult to deal with the outbreak. title: U.S., China Fuel Rise in World-Wide Military Spending
summary: As Washington and Beijing compete, other countries raise expenditures to hedge against uncertainty. MUNICH-Global competition between the U.S. and China is spurring countries around the world to increase their military spending, according to a new report by an international think tank that reported the biggest increase in more than a decade.

title: All About Al Forno
summary: If mac and cheese went to graduate school in Italy, it might come back looking like one of these refined takes on baked pasta. IN THE CALIFORNIA kitchen of my childhood, baked pasta was synonymous with macaroni and cheese-the go-to choice for my birthday and any other occasion where I was in charge of the menu. When I finally got my own kitchen, I tried my hand at all sorts of pastas baked in the oven, crunchy on top and luscious within. I still have tattered instructions for a many-mushroom lasagna that I cut from a magazine in the late 1970s and pasted into a red notebook designated specifically for noodles and rice. Also in that book is my favorite recipe for conchiglie al forno with mushrooms and radicchio.

title: U.S. and Taliban Reach First Step of Peace Deal
summary: Initial period of 'reduced violence' set; if it holds further talks would take place. MUNICH-The U.S. government and the Afghan Taliban have agreed to the first step of a peace deal, a senior Trump administration official said Friday, a major milestone after months of talks over ending a war that has gone on for more than 18 years.

title: American Shoppers Unmoved by Stock Market Records
summary: Wall Street can shake its pom-poms all it wants, but Americans still aren't rushing out to spend. Wall Street can shake its pom-poms all it wants, but Americans still aren't rushing out to spend.

title: How to Go All Nine Months Without Buying Maternity Wear
summary: In a fashion landscape full of voluminous shapes, avoiding the dreaded temporary wardrobe has never been easier. ABOUT A MONTH ago, I finished getting dressed, turned toward the mirror, and realized I was beginning to look like Winnie-the-Pooh. Five months pregnant, I saw my bare belly protruding from under the hem of my box-cut T-shirt and above the barely buttoning waistband of my ankle-crop jeans. I had over four months to go; this would not do. I needed to find stylish clothing that would take me through to the end of my pregnancy, when I would be most rumbly in my tumbly.

title: Colum McCann Wants to Knock Readers Off Balance
summary: In his new novel 'Apeirogon,' the author of 'Let the Great World Spin' experiments with form to tell the stories of two grief-stricken fathers in the Middle East. Colum McCann's sweeping new novel has a simple origin. "I had my heart blown open," he explains in his soft Irish brogue, alluding to a poem by his countryman Seamus Heaney: "As big soft buffetings come at the car sideways / And catch the heart off guard and blow it open." What had struck Mr. McCann so forcefully were two stories he heard in 2015 in the West Bank town of Beit Jala, just south of Jerusalem.

But Mr. Biden had already moved on, flying earlier in the day to South Carolina for a campaign launch party as he sought to put his poor showing behind him.

That became even clearer one week later, when the Academy Awards registered less than one-quarter of the big game's TV audience.

Investors are understandably skeptical.

title: When Your Ancestry Test Entangles Others
summary: Today's DNA kits can reveal secrets that affect not just your own family but strangers as well. Should one person's right to know take precedence over another's life narrative?.

title: Your Broker and You: New Rules, Old Tricks
summary: New regulations will soon restrict some unsavory practices, but they don't absolve investors of the need to remain vigilant. Brokers will soon be getting the rule book thrown at them. Investors still need to read the writing on the wall.

title: 'The King at the Edge of the World' Review: A Muslim in Elizabethan England
summary: In 1601, as Queen Elizabeth is dying without a direct heir, her spymasters enlist a brilliant but guileless Turkish doctor as part of their plot to determine whether King James VI of Scotland has secret Catholic sympathies. Beginning with "Prague," his clever 2002 debut set among a new Lost Generation of young expats in postcommunist Budapest, Arthur Phillips has tickled and tested readers with one brainy, playful novel after another. His imaginatively peripatetic books have varied widely, but they share an underlying concern with authenticity, self-delusion and dissembling. His sixth novel, "The King at the Edge of the World," extends his exploration of uncertainty with a cunning tale of espionage and court intrigue regarding the religious disposition of Queen Elizabeth I's most likely successor-King James VI of Scotland.

title: Should Parents Try to Spend the Same Amount of Money on Each Child?
summary: Sometimes what seems most equitable isn't necessarily the most fair. Most parents would probably say they love all of their children equally and don't play favorites. Keeping the scales balanced when it comes to family finances, however, is more complicated.

title: Fiction: Between Here and the Hereafter
summary: A bug in the afterlife's official protocol sends a soul back to Earth until further notice.. At the start of Amy Bonnaffons's "The Regrets" (Little, Brown, 295 pages, $27), Thomas Barrett gets into a motorcycle accident, killing himself and his best friend. Only not quite-due to an "institutional error" on the part of the afterlife's bureaucrats, Thomas is "insufficiently dead" and has to be sent back to Earth to wait things out for a few months until exit procedures are brought into order.

title: 'Einstein in Bohemia' and 'Einstein on the Run' Review: Genius Will Travel
summary: After fleeing to England in the face of Nazi death threats, Einstein was given secret refuge in an MP's country house.. 'I must confess that biographies have rarely attracted or fascinated me," Albert Einstein wrote in 1949, in a preface to one about him. Hundreds more have appeared since then, and into this crowded field come two focusing on particular topics in Einstein's life: his residency in Prague before the First World War and his flight to Britain before the Second. They could hardly be more different.

title: 'Until the End of Time' Review: Written in the Stars
summary: A physicist's ambitious attempt to show how the universal human search for meaning emerges from the laws of the physical world.. A theoretical physicist at Columbia University, Brian Greene has tackled string theory, the nature of the cosmos and other grand subjects in superbly written bestsellers such as "The Fabric of the Cosmos" and "The Elegant Universe." In his latest book, "Until the End of Time," he ventures into territory well beyond that where physicists typically roam. He steps out beyond the quest to understand the physical universe, its beginning and fate, to our search as humans for meaning and purpose, the interaction of mind and matter, to speculate on a new kind of unified theory of practically everything.

title: 'The Man in the Red Coat' Review: The Toast of Belle Époque Paris
summary: 'It's not about you, it's about the coat,' John Singer Sargent said to his crimson-clad sitter.. Biographers in the 19th century wrote the histories of Great Men, talking up their achievements and accentuating their professional and social status. Since those times, the craft of biography has been transformed. The challenge to the biographer of our day is to illuminate not only the public but the private life, the vulnerabilities as well as the strengths of a man or woman, to delve into the interior world of the subject and focus on the telling detail that will bring the subject alive. But, as Julian Barnes reminds us in "The Man in the Red Coat," biography is always full of holes. "We cannot know," he writes: There is no such thing as the whole truth when the subject is dead, the biographer dependent on hearsay, someone's memoirs, someone else's diaries-and yet we want, we expect, to know. So how does Mr. Barnes evoke the life of an enigmatic hero of Belle Époque Paris, a surgeon known to "everyone" in his day but lost to us-how can he bring him vividly before our eyes?

title: Mysteries: 'Djinn Patrol on the Purple Line'
summary: In Deepa Anappara's debut novel, a crime-show-watching Indian youth recruits two friends to track down a missing schoolmate.. Deepa Anappara's moving "Djinn Patrol on the Purple Line" (Random House, 347 pages $27) stars Jai, an easily distracted 9-year-old living in a poor neighborhood in a present-day Indian metropolis. Jai, who narrates the majority of the novel, likes watching crime shows on television and fantasizes about earning fame as "the Greatest Detective on Earth," hunting villains "in the smog-dark lanes" of the local bazaar.

title: Children's Books: Chilly, Exacting Men
summary: Lindbergh foresaw that the lightest plane carrying the most fuel had the best chance to be first across the Atlantic.. Early in 1927, a 25-year-old college dropout named Charles Lindbergh had ideas for an airplane that could take him across the hitherto unspannable distance between New York and Paris-and win the fat prize awaiting the crew that could pull the feat off first. Lindbergh foresaw that the lightest plane carrying the most fuel had the best chance.

summary: Some airlines are ditching seatback screens on domestic flights-forcing fliers to watch films on their own phones, tablets or laptops. WHEN THE first seatback video screens starting appearing on airplanes around 30 years ago, the screen was tinier than the average display on today's cellphones. Yet it offered that ultimate perk: relief from the tedium and claustrophobia of air travel.

summary: Firings of the Communist Party secretaries of Hubei province and Wuhan signal Beijing's disapproval of their handling of Covid-19 epidemic. summary: Coming off a strong season, the NFL is antsy to renegotiate its media deals worth tens of billions. The key: agreeing to a new labor deal with its players first.. title: Is This the End of the Road for Mercedes's G-Wagens?
summary: As an off-road SUV with luxury styling and a six-figure price tag, the 2020 Mercedes-AMG G 63 is a boxy bundle of contradictions. Dan Neil explains why organized crime's favorite SUV is a thrill to drive and not long for this world. THE 2020 Mercedes-AMG G 63 is a boxy bundle of contradictions. For example: This is an extreme off-road vehicle, right? Yet it is fitted with chrome-tipped underhung side pipes; shod with 22-inch cross-spoke wheels; and our tester ($186,395) was tinted with an impeccable, once-in-a-lifetime matte green-gray finish (Dark Olive Green Magno). So what happens if you aim your new Geländewagen down a wooded trail and briers scratch it? Oh, too late.

title: 5G Sends a Confusing Signal
summary: Marketing hype remains hot for next-gen wireless technology, but network expansion seems to have slowed. How is 5G really doing? The answer, it seems, is complicated.

title: Editor Kristina O'Neill on the March 2020 Issue
summary: Our editor in chief on the women's spring fashion issue, starring cover model Adut Akech. Our March Women's Fashion issue ventures into worlds of daring and boldness, starting with our cover featuring 20-year-old superstar model Adut Akech. In a vivid portrait shot by photographer Mikael Jansson, a smiling Akech wears bright colors that capture the season's buoyant, can-do energy, a spirit her life story exemplifies. Born in what is now South Sudan, she spent her early years in one of Kenya's largest refugee camps before immigrating to Australia. Now one of the industry's most sought-after talents, she's leveraging her fame to call attention to inclusivity and the dignity of refugees.

title: Contributors to the March 2020 Issue
summary: Photographer Ethan James Green, writer Chris Jones and others who contributed to the women's spring fashion issue. For this issue, photographer Ethan James Green, stylist Anastasia Barbieri and prop stylist Julia Wagner traveled to Cartagena, Colombia, for a fashion portfolio with model Malgosia Bela. But the photo shoot's true luminaries were the birds. "The biggest challenge on the shoot was to make Titi the bird move onto set and pose with Malgosia. [Titi] was acting like a real star," says Barbieri. For another shot, holding the attention of a spectacled owl proved tricky, and the team had to be creative. "To get the owl to look straight to camera, one of the bird handlers pulled a dead mouse out of his pocket and dangled it right above Ethan's head," Wagner recalls. "That's how we got the shot."

title: What Angélique Kidjo Can't Live Without
summary: The singer-songwriter and activist shares the objects most meaningful to her, from a cherished microphone to a Beninese bucket. "That statue of Lissa/Mawu, the god and goddess of creation, was given to me by the Benin minister of culture a couple years back. Next to it, in the rear, Logozo was my first breakthrough album and my first full-length one with a major label. In front, that 1962 Neumann U 67 microphone-whooo, it sounds so good. I have such a dynamic voice: I can go very low, I can go very soft, and I can belt it out. Not many microphones can take all of those different types of voices and deliver it as pure and as warm and as beautiful as I give it. On the far left, my mom, when my baby, Naïma, was born, came all the way from Benin with these pink buckets. The way we wash a newborn in Benin is very particular: When you're giving a bath you remold the child's body. It takes an hour and the baby's like clay. Inside the bucket, one of the Polaroids is of me starting my career, full of hope, fearless, on tour. The community that you create on tour is so important for the music you play onstage. Those bracelets in front were made specifically for my album Ayé. We had to copy the jewelry because it was too expensive for me to buy at the time. I had another fearless look-like an Amazonian but completely modern. The Paris Match magazine photo is from 2018, when I was asked to sing in Paris for the centennial of the First World War. I accepted on the condition that I would be there to pay tribute to the African soldiers who died for peace and the democracy we live in today. In the back, those drums are amazing because they have many different notes depending on where you hit them. You can't hit them with strong, rigid sticks. It has to be very soft, like with your hands, very gentle. With the square drum, you have to see it played to understand the ingenuity of human beings to create instruments and to express emotion."

title: Former Banking Behemoth Changes a 300-Year-Old Brand Tainted by Crisis

Their networks, historically used by banks to issue cards and merchants to accept cards, handled more than $13 trillion worth of purchases last year.

A group linked to Republicans spent over $2 million trying to shape the Democratic primary, boosting a long-shot candidate against frontrunner Cal Cunningham, who has the backing of the national Democratic apparatus. Their TV ads highlight progressive policies like Medicare for All and the Green New Deal, which Republicans hope will push Cunningham to the left.

title: Canada's Biggest Railroad to Shut Down Key Corridor Over Blockades

title: Trump's Worst Enemy
summary: He needs to stop tweeting about cases and let Barr do his job.. After his Senate impeachment acquittal, we wrote that President Trump's history is that he can't stand prosperity. The President's relentless popping off this week about the sentencing of supporter Roger Stone has hurt himself, his Justice Department, and the proper understanding of executive power. That's a notable trifecta of self-destructive behavior even by his standards.
